Welcome to your documentation space!How to Publish an Existing Report to Demo SiteHow to Make Tableau Report Adjustments

## Featured pages

Content by Label is used to display lists of pages, blog posts, or attachments that have particular labels. It's great for curating content you want to show on your overview page.For example, you could display a list of all pages that have the label 'feature-shipped' and include the word 'Blueprint', or to list any pages with the label 'meeting-notes' that youve been mentioned in.To add the Content by Label element:When editing type /Find Content by label in the dropdownSelect InsertTo edit the Content by Label element:Select the placeholder. The floating toolbar appears.Select EditModify the parameters. Your changes are saved as you go.Resume editing the page, and the panel closes.
## Recently updated

Your changes are saved as you go.Resume editing the page, and the panel closes.
## Recently updated

To add the Recently updated element:When editing type /Find Recently updated in the dropdownSelect InsertTo edit the Recently updated element:Select the placeholder. The floating toolbar appears.Select EditModify the parameters. Your changes are saved as you go.Resume editing the page, and the panel closes.
## Popular labels

Display a list of the most popular labels used throughout your Confluence site or within a space. A popular label is a label that has been added to many pages.To add the Popular labels element:When editing type /Find Popular labels in the dropdownSelect InsertTo edit the Popular labels element:Select the placeholder. The floating toolbar appears.Select EditModify the parameters. Your changes are saved as you go.Resume editing the page, and the panel closes.

> Tip: Here are some tips to get you started. You can edit this page to see how it works!

## 1. Create a page

- Click "Create" and select "Blank Page" to create your first page.
- New pages are created as children of the page you are currently viewing.

## 2. Add to your page

- Click "Edit" to enter the Confluence editor and use the page layouts feature to structure your content using sections and columns.
- Use headings to format your text and drag and drop images into your page to provide visual interest.
- Click "Insert" and select "Other Macros" to add macros for navigation, special formatting and other media.

On this page:
## 3. Organise your pages

Here are some tips for organising your content.

- Change the page order

The sidebar on the left displays your pages in a hierarchy. If you have Space Administrator permissions you can click "Space Tools" > "Reorder Pages" to move pages around.

- Add labels

trator permissions you can click "Space Tools" > "Reorder Pages" to move pages around.

- Add labels

Labels help keep pages organised and make it easier for you to find the information you need. Click "Labels" at the bottom of a page to add or edit. The "Related pages" section on this page uses labels too!

- Make templates

Standardise and speed up the page creation process with templates. You can create and format a template with page layouts, standard headings and instructional text for hints and guidelines. Check out our sample page on
                "[Making a template]"

Related pages

Give your authors a helping hand by using templates in your documentation space. You will need Space Administrator permissions to create templates.

To create a template:

1. Go to "Space Tools" in the sidebar, select "Content Tools" and create a new template.
2. Click "Page Layout" and add sections and columns to your page.
3. Add headings and sub-headings as needed.
4. Choose "Instructional Text" from the "Template" menu and add text that is only visible in the editor.
5. Save your template.

Your template will become available in the Create dialog for this space.

Related pages

> Info: Confluence Administrators can also make templates that are available across your whole Confluence instance.

metadata.title: Presales Documentation - Getting started - Making a template

## Team mission

Add your team's mission here.

## Team mission

## Project information

- Use this panel to add information about OKRs, strategy and links to Jira projects
-

## Roadmap overview

Use this roadmap macro to provide a visual overview of the roadmap. Lanes can be used to capture projects and bars to show schedule for features or parts of a project

## Detailed quarterly roadmap

The roadmap shows the sequence in which you execute on features. In addition to strategic priority, the execution order is dependent on factors such as team composition and external dependencies. Features from different broader initatives may get interleaved. If you have your roadmap set up in Jira, you can embed that below.

### Q1

ives may get interleaved. If you have your roadmap set up in Jira, you can embed that below.

### Q1

| Feature | Initiative | Dates | Priority | Effort | Status | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| List feature | List initiative that feature belongs to | Type /date to add a date range | / / | / / | / / | Link to project pages and epics |
|  |  |  |  |  |  |  |

## Overview

| Name | Type /link to add the known error's ticket |
| --- | --- |
| Status | /  / |
| Version | e.g., 2.3 |
| Owner | @ mention the owner |
| Related errors | Type /link to add tickets related to the known error |
| Summary | Summary |

## Error details

| Description | Provide a detailed explanation of the known error's causes and how it was discovered |
| --- | --- |
| Impacted services services | List the services impacted by the known error |
| Primary configuration item | Describe the main configuration item involved in the known error |
| Steps to reproduce | Summarize the steps you need to take to recreate the known error |
| Workaround | Describe how your team was able to continue working while the known error was still unresolved |
| Solution | Describe how the known error can be resolved |

## Get the most out of your documentation space

Labels are key words that you can add to pages and attachments to make them easier to group and find. For example, you could add the `recruiting` label to all pages related to finding and hiring new talent. That would allow you to easily see, display, and search for related pages.

Anyone with permission to edit a page can add labels to it. You can add labels to a page while youre editing it or after its published, when youre viewing the page.

You can also insert a list of different labels to make it easy for people to find important pages. Choose from:

- Popular labels: a list of the most popular labels in your space
- Labels list: list all labels in your space in alphabetical order
- Content by label: list all pages tagged with a specific label

each list of dynamic content

When editing, type ' / ' to find and add each list of dynamic content

## Take your Confluence space to the next level

Extend the capabilities of your Confluence pages by adding extra functionality or including dynamic content.

To add functionality:

1. Type ' / ' to open the list of items available to use
2. Find the item to be inserted and select it
3. Select Insert

## Useful elements for Documentation space

[Livesearch](https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-livesearch-macro/)

Add the Livesearch to a page to provide a fully customizable search field. When someone starts typing into the search field, Confluence will suggest matching pages, blogs, or comments.

metadata.title: Get the most out of your documentation space

content:
one starts typing into the search field, Confluence will suggest matching pages, blogs, or comments.

To add Livesearch:When editing, type ' / 'Find the item to be inserted and select itSelect InsertTo edit Livesearch:Select the element placeholder. The floating toolbar appears.Select Edit. The right panel opens.Modify the parameters. Your changes are saved as you go.Resume editing the page, and the panel closes.

[Recently updated content](https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-recently-updated-macro/)

Add Recently updated content to a page to show a list of pages, blogs, files, and comments that have been created or edited recently.

metadata.title: Get the most out of your documentation space

content:
to show a list of pages, blogs, files, and comments that have been created or edited recently. 

To add the Recently updated content:When editing, type ' / 'Find the item to be inserted and select itSelect InsertTo edit the Recently Updated parameters:Select the element placeholder. The floating toolbar appears.Select Edit. The right panel opens.Modify the parameters. Your changes are saved as you go.Resume editing the page, and the panel closes.[Excerpt and Excerpt include](https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-excerpt-macro/)

Add Excerpt to a page to define a snippet of content to be re-used on another page.

This is great single sourcing important information. For example you could provide the contact details and dates from each project page on a summary page. When the info is updated in the excerpt, it will flow through to all the other places it is used.

metadata.title: Get the most out of your documentation space

content:
e. When the info is updated in the excerpt, it will flow through to all the other places it is used.

In the Confluence editor, select View moreFind the Excerpt element and select it. The placeholder is added and the right panel opens.Give it a name so you can reference it on another page using the Excerpt Include element. If you don't give the element a name, you will only be able to include the content from the first Excerpt on this page.Select the Hide Excerpted Content check box if you want the content to be hidden when this page is published.Add your content inside the Excerpt placeholder in the page. Most of the formatting options can be used, and elements in the toolbar can be inserted.You can also type  /  into the page to bring up the same list you'd see by selecting from the toolbar.To add the Excerpt Include to a page:When editing, type ' / 'Find the item to be inserted and select itSelect Insert

[Skip to Video (Turkish)](https://drive.google.com/file/d/19jMpoRDCp649QUdcKvtAmqDyJ6rfsHIY/view?usp=sharing)

1. First, navigate to the source demo site we want to export the report on.

1. Then, select the report that we want to export.

1. Take the name of the report from the URL as shown below, and note it. (You will use it later)

1. In order to export the report to the desired demo, first you need to donwload the report to your local computer. In order to do that,  navigate to Tableau Server tableau.inventanalytics.com/#/site
2. The reports from the Demo are located in Omega site under Tableau Server, so choose that as site.

1. Then, choose “Explore” on the left navigation column.

1. The reports are generally in the Default Folder.

1. Then find the report name that you extracted from the URL earlier (step 3) and open it.

1. Download the report to your local computer.

metadata.title: How to Publish an Existing Report to Another Demo Site

content:
extracted from the URL earlier (step 3) and open it.

1. Download the report to your local computer.

1. Open the report on your local computer using Tableau Desktop.
2. Then navigate to File->Workbook Locale-> change the language from Automatic (User Locale) to English (United States)

1. In the upper ribbon check Server-> Signed in to https://tableau.inventanalytics.com (site_name). If the site_name is different than the site you want to publish your report on, navigate to Sign in to Another Site… and sign in.

1. Then if there are changes that needs to be done, do the changes. After it’s finished, navigate to Server → Publish Workbook

1. In the popped window, choose Location = Default

1. Then, check the Data Sources-> Publish Type. “Embedded in workbook” option needs to be selected.

1. Then navigate to Sheets, if all of them selected click “None“, and select the Sheets that you want to publish.

1. Click “Publish“

metadata.title: How to Publish an Existing Report to Another Demo Site

content:
l of them selected click “None“, and select the Sheets that you want to publish.

1. Click “Publish“

1. You can see in the target demo site page of Tableau Server that our report is published.

1. Then, navigate to the target demo page. i.e: grocerydemo.next.inventanalytics.com
2. Click Report Management under Admin section

1. Navigate to “Available Reports“. Select the sheet that you want to publish then click “Publish”.

1. If you want, you can change the name of the Report.

1. Find the suitable parent category that you want to publish your report under.

1. Select the Customer and Role (there is only one option usually), then click “Create“.

1. The publish is done! You can check the report under the parent category that you chose when you published.

metadata.title: How to Publish an Existing Report to Another Demo Site

content:
When publishing a report, it is advised to make the “Details“ section blank when loading. Since it can be accessed through clicking a point in the “Summary” section. To address this issue, below solution can be utilized.

To make the report open faster you can make the “Details“ section of the report blank when the report is opened. In order to do that navigate to Dashboard-> Actions

While publishing, on the pop-out window navigate to Add Action → Filter… Then make sure only the source is selected on the “Source Sheets” and only the target is selected on the “Target Sheets” . Select “Exclude All values” then click OK on the both pop-out windows.

metadata.title: How to Make a Report Load Faster?

content: This section is dedicated to give information about useful tips and troubleshooting solutions in the context of Tableau use cases.

There are limitations to make changes on a report in Tableau Server. In that case we download the report on our local computer, do the changes and publish it. In that case the report size is important.  If the file is too big, the data size needs to be decreased then the report needs to be refreshed. And then it needs to be downloaded to work on. Here are the steps to accomplish what just said.

[Skip to video (Turkish)](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1natcNEDM_if_Q8LCGWMwWMgZvFBGoZ0y/view?usp=sharing)

1. First, navigate to the report in Tableau Server.

1. Then, navigate to the notebbok in Databricks in order to make changes in the report data.

1. Then we start the cluster on the notebook.

1. To decrease the size of data, different options can be taken. You can do it by only selecting a single product, a single store and a single day. In this case we select only one store. And we run the notebook.

metadata.title: How to Make Tableau Report Adjustments

content:
ct, a single store and a single day. In this case we select only one store. And we run the notebook.

1. After the notebook is run, go back to Tableau Server then ….->Refresh Extracts. On the pop-out window, navigate to Refresh Now tab and click Full Refresh.

1. You can view the refresh process under Jobs section as shown below.

1. After the Job is completed, go back to the report and download it.

1. To format a column on a sheet, just click the ”Go To Sheet” icon and on the sheet, right click the column. Then format the column as you please. In the right the changing of shaders and Font colors are shown.

1. After all changes are made,, make sure the Server is correctly showing under then “Server” tab as shown below. (In the below capture,, the target is Grocery)

1. Navigate to Server → Publish

1. In the pop-out window, select the sheets that you want to publish. In the below example,, it is a sheet that is already on the Tableau Server so the sheets are automatically selected.

metadata.title: How to Make Tableau Report Adjustments

content:
mple,, it is a sheet that is already on the Tableau Server so the sheets are automatically selected.

1. Under the “Data Sources” section, check the Authentication pane. If the underlying data source is a non-refreshable source (i.e Client Database that you don’t have access to) select “Refresh not enabled“ else select “Allow refresh access“. Then click “Publish“.
2. Then navigate to Databricks notebook that you filtered the data in order to decrease its size. To revert that, simply comment out the filtering code snippet and run the notebook again.
3. Go back to Tableau Server and … → Refresh Extracts. Click “Full Refresh” under the “Refresh Now” pane.

1. Congratulations, the report is published and the data is refreshed! You can monitor the refresh process as shown in step 6.

metadata.title: How to Make Tableau Report Adjustments

content:
1. Sometimes credentials must be entered when publishing a Tableau report to a Tableau Server. In order to access those credentials, open Databricks and navigate to the target Workspace.

1. Then, navigate to “SQL Warehouses” on the left pane and select the target warehouse.

1. You will find the asked credentials there. Below are the asked credentials highlighted. Enter the credentials and publish the report. Note that you will need the “Personal Access Token“ later on, so it is advised to note it down.

metadata.title: How to Access DBX Credentials When Publishing a Report

content: This section is dedicated to give information about useful tips and troubleshooting solutions in the context of Databricks use cases.

[Skip to video (Turkish)](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1OYc8q_kfyWR9mLq9tuxcXjNY75JOyyev/view?usp=sharing)

1. First, download the report that you want to transfer on your local computer. (How to Publish an Existing Report to Another Demo Site Steps 1-10)
2. Open Databricks and create a notebook. Define your target and source paths.

1. Inspect your report and your dataset, if you notice some fields in the report that the data doesn’t have (i.e Product Groups,Store Descriptions) note the fields down.
2. If your dataset is too large. You can filter down on a single product_id, store_id or a single day. Then write your data on your predefined destination.
3. Then use the target location (in above example its lsrc_final_path variable’s value) to create a table in Databricks as shown below.

1. Also check the script for the additional data that has been described in step 3. If other datasets are not created as tables, create those tables as shown below.

metadata.title: How to Adapt a Report to the Demo Environment

content:
escribed in step 3. If other datasets are not created as tables, create those tables as shown below.

1. Open the report that you downloaded in step 1 and navigate to Data Sources.

1. If the Tableau server asks for some credentials, take a look at this tip How to Access DBX Credentials When Publishing a Report
2. Remove existing data from Data Sources.

1. Under the “Table“ pane, search for the data that you wrote in the final path and drag it to the center.

1. (Optional) If you will join the other tables, right click the data then click “Open“.

i. Drag and drop the other tables to the right frame.

ii. Click on the join type and adjust it based on your data.

iii. If there are any type mismatches between joined on columns you can cast them as a preffered type as shown below.

iiii. Click “Update Now“ after you arrange the join definition.

1. Navigate back to the sheet.

metadata.title: How to Adapt a Report to the Demo Environment

content:
ow.

iiii. Click “Update Now“ after you arrange the join definition.

1. Navigate back to the sheet.

1. You will notice some problems in the sheet. These are based on some values that are not properly matched or joined. To solve this problem you can simply drop the fields or right click on the problematic field and click “Edit“

1. On the pop-out window note the field name.

1. Find the field name in the left pane, right click and select “Replace References“

1. Select the correct reference and click “OK“

metadata.title: How to Adapt a Report to the Demo Environment

content:
ft pane, right click and select “Replace References“

1. Select the correct reference and click “OK“

1. Publish the report on the target site. You can find detailed guide on that here:
2. Then navigate to Databricks notebook that you filtered the data in order to decrease its size. To revert that, simply comment out the filtering code snippet and run the notebook again.
3. Go back to Tableau Server and … → Refresh Extracts. Click “Full Refresh” under the “Refresh Now” pane.
4. Congratulations, the report is published and the data is refreshed! You can monitor the refresh process as shown in step 6.

metadata.title: How to Adapt a Report to the Demo Environment

content:
### Skip to Video (Turkish)

# Omega UI

## Inventory Management

### Control Tower

Control Tower is a summary screen that shows daily data. Values like daily orders, sales & inventory, availability, lost sales, weeks of supply, trends, promotions and alerts can be seen and accessed through Control Tower. User can click any metric from Control Tower to navigate to the more detailed report regarding the metric. To find detailed information about its attributes, you can check here: [Control Tower - User Guide]

Control Tower

### Replenishment Order Planning

Replenishment Order Planning screen is a screen that shows product level daily data about replenishment transfers between sources and stores. It also helps the user monitor the target and actual replenishment quantities, min-max targets. The user can edit or create replenishment orders through this screen. To find detailed information, you can check here: [Store Replenishment Orders - User Guide]

Replenishment Order Planning

rmation, you can check here: [Store Replenishment Orders - User Guide]

Replenishment Order Planning

### Forecast Review/Edit

Forecast Screen is a screen that shows store-product, product level forecasted targets and actual values to monitor metrics like Sales Quantity, Consensus etc. User can edit the targets or filter the data to suit his/her needs. To find more detailed information about the Forecast Screen, you can check here: [Forecast Review & Edit - User Guide]

Forecast Review/Edit

### Product-Store Groups

Product-Store Groups screen is a screen that user can create or edit product-store, products only or store only groups based on his/her needs in order to utilize this groups in operations like filtering in other screens. (i.e Florida Stores) Also Store Master and Product Master data can be accessed through here. To find more info: [Product Store Groups - User Guide]

Product-Store Groups

### Parameters Configuration

d more info: [Product Store Groups - User Guide]

Product-Store Groups

### Parameters Configuration

Parameters Configuration screen is a screen where user can create or manage rules or constraints to be considered in Inventory Management. (i.e. each product must be at lest 10 units in each store). To find more information: [Parameters Configuration - User Guide]

Parameter Configuration

### Alerts Review

Alerts Screen is a screen where problems within the Invent system can be monitored and their details can be accessed through. Problems including Store Replenishment can be filtered down and accessed through here. To find more info: [Alerts Review - User Guide]

Alerts Review

## Allocation

### Ad-Hoc Run Screen

To find more info: [Alerts Review - User Guide]

Alerts Review

## Allocation

### Ad-Hoc Run Screen

Ad-Hoc Screen is a screen that user can utilize in order to create one-time allocation orders from supplier or warehouse to stores in scenarios like preparing a new Promotion etc. User can configure the Forecast Configuration on this screen (Brick&Mortar Demand, BOPIS Demand or Fullfillment Demand). Run sub screen helps the user to monitor the allocation process. User can oversee how many SKUs are in the allocation, how many stores are supplied with these SKUs, how much % of Inventory is being used before and after the allocation and how much % of Inventory is available before and after the allocation. In the Results pane user can approve or reject the Ad-Hoc allocation.

Run Result Screen

## Forecast

### Forecast Enrich

er can approve or reject the Ad-Hoc allocation.

Run Result Screen

## Forecast

### Forecast Enrich

Forecast Enrich screen is a screen that shows similarity ratios between products and between stores. It also has a substitute products section where the metrics of an items different sizes colors etc. can be accessed. This screen is particularly useful in scenarios when a new product is going to be launched and by accessing the substitute products, the user can have an idea of its performance.

Forecast Enrich

# Data Sources

## Databricks

Data preparation is done through Databricks. For example the Allocation data is under [https://adb-1214565888048763.3.azuredatabricks.net/browse/folders/2531166829543585?o=1214565888048763](https://adb-1214565888048763.3.azuredatabricks.net/browse/folders/2531166829543585?o=1214565888048763)

Allocation Example

For some screens GBQ connection must be done. In those cases values api_endpoint, run_date, rootPath must be declared as below example.

t be done. In those cases values api_endpoint, run_date, rootPath must be declared as below example.

GBQ Connection

If a format related problem arises, it can be checked from DataDock or by asking support from the Cheetah Team.

## Troubleshooting

To check if the screens are correct and aligned with the data, we can navigate to a screen from the Demo site and also the source GBQ page. If we look at the below example, we can see 21K and 4.1K Product Locations in total.

Control Tower Capture

We can see there is 25.1K product locations.

GBQ Capture

When we check the source GBQ table, we can see that there is also 25.1k rows, so the screen is aligned with the data.

Also run_date column is important as it must be aligned between the screen and the GBQ source. If some data is not visible in the screens, checking the last_run table from GBQ can be useful.

Last Run Table

## Special Case for Product Master and Store Master

n table from GBQ can be useful.

Last Run Table

## Special Case for Product Master and Store Master

Store Master and Product Master tables must be written in a folder called default as demonstrated below.

Product-Store Master Example

## Allocation Example

When the user creates a new Ad-Hoc Allocation from the screen, the allocation will show the status of “Pending“.  It creates the input folder in the blob correctly, in order to accomplish this task fully a new folder called “output“ must be created in the same path as the “input“ folder and the results.csv needs to be transferred there manually.

Then to write the files to GBQ,, the run_id must be entered executed as shown below.

Writing to GBQ

## Github

If there are changes made in the columns (types,names etc.) it can be checked from [https://github.com/inventanalytics/omega-ui/blob/main/omega_ui/config_metadata.yml](https://github.com/inventanalytics/omega-ui/blob/main/omega_ui/config_metadata.yml) as shown below.

(https://github.com/inventanalytics/omega-ui/blob/main/omega_ui/config_metadata.yml) as shown below.

config_metadata.yml

Also column descriptions can be checked from the related Confluence pages.

The calculation behind the metrics in the screens can be seen by the related .py file under the Github Repo. For example for store_rpl_orders the file is [https://github.com/inventanalytics/omega-ui/blob/main/omega_ui/store_rpl_orders.py](https://github.com/inventanalytics/omega-ui/blob/main/omega_ui/store_rpl_orders.py).

### Outline

1. What is Pricing Demo? How to Access It?
2. What is Available in the Pricing Demo?
3. Where is the Data Stored?
4. Which Datasets Affect the Demo in TeknosaPricingTest?
5. Sample Queries for Data Retrieval and Modification

1. What is Pricing Demo? How to Access It?

Pricing Demo is a demonstration screen designed to provide insights into the capabilities of Invent’s Pricing product. It can be accessed via the following link: [Pricing Demo](https://demo.inventanalytics.com/pricing#dashboard) or through the Pricing Menu on the demo page.

1. What is Available in the Pricing Demo?

The Pricing Demo provides pricing recommendations across three key areas:

- Competitive Price Optimization
- Price Optimization
- Clearing Price

It includes historical competitor price data, product details, inventory, and sales information. Additionally, the projected impact of the recommended sales price can be compared with the expected impact based on current pricing.

ct of the recommended sales price can be compared with the expected impact based on current pricing.

1. Where is the Data Stored?

To access the Pricing Demo data, ensure that Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio is installed on your computer. Access permission to the TeknosaPricingTest database is required.

1. Which Datasets Affect the Demo in TeknosaPricingTest?

- [TeknosaPricingTest].[pricing].[PricingResults]: Contains all details of the displayed results.The demo results are found under Run IDs 1370, 1371, and 1373.Status values: 0 - pending, 1 - approved, 2 - ignored, 3 - no-change.Calculations such as DeltaPrice and DeltaProfit are performed in the table, not on the interface. Therefore, modifications should be made in the table when necessary.
- [TeknosaPricingTest].[pricing].[CompetitorPrices]: Stores competitor price information for the analyzed product.If the displayed data does not match the expected values, check for date inconsistencies or missing competitorId and price entries in PricingResults.
- [TeknosaPricingTest].[pricing].[ProductDailySummary]: Contains sales data for the product.Any errors or changes in calculations should be corrected in this table rather than on the interface.

ny errors or changes in calculations should be corrected in this table rather than on the interface.
- [TeknosaPricingTest].[model].[Products]: Stores product codes displayed on the interface.Helps match products efficiently.Any modifications to product details should be made in this table.

1. Sample Queries for Data Retrieval and Modification

Before making any modifications, it is crucial to back up the data to avoid irreversible changes.

Retrieve Data

SELECT [Id]

,[RunId]

,[ProductId]

,[AlgorithmId]

,[PriceBeforeRun]

,[NewPrice]

,[GrossMarginBeforeRun]

,[NewGrossMargin]

,[DeltaPrice]

,[MatchedCompetitorId]

,[Status]

,[InteractionId]

,[SalesBeforeRun]

,[UnitCostBeforeRun]

,[DeltaGrossMargin]

,[NewSales]

,[DeltaSales]

,[RevenueBeforeRun]

,[NewRevenue]

,[DeltaRevenue]

,[ProfitBeforeRun]

,[NewProfit]

,[DeltaProfit]

,[NaiveElasticity]

,[ModifiedPrice]

,[MatchedCompetitorPrice]

,[SellThroughTarget]

,[SellThroughRateBeforeRun]

,[NewSellThroughRate]

,[MatchedCompetitorPrice]

,[SellThroughTarget]

,[SellThroughRateBeforeRun]

,[NewSellThroughRate]

FROM [TeknosaPricingTest].[pricing].[PricingResults]

WHERE RunId in (1373)

Change Status

UPDATE [TeknosaPricingTest].[pricing].[PricingResults]

SET Status = 0

WHERE [RunId] = 1373

AND ProductId = 52645;

Adjust Date

UPDATE [TeknosaPricingTest].[pricing].[CompetitorPrices]

SET [Date] = DATEADD(DAY, -5, [Date])

WHERE ProductId = 52645;
